gameDetails.matchup: Minnesota Timberwolves vs Oklahoma City Thunder

recentPerformance.hitRate: Double-digit dogs covering well in NBA
recentPerformance.cushion: 10.5 is massive spread for quality opponent

keyFactors.title: Inflated Line Due to Public Perception
keyFactors.description: OKC's 17-1 start created public overreaction. Thunder became media darlings and line inflated beyond true value.

keyFactors.title: 10.5 Points is Massive for Playoff Team
keyFactors.description: Minnesota is a playoff-caliber opponent with Anthony Edwards. Double-digit spreads rarely hold against quality competition.

keyFactors.title: Thunder on Back-to-Back
keyFactors.description: OKC playing second night of back-to-back after road game. Fatigue factor works against home team.

keyFactors.title: Sharp Money Movement
keyFactors.description: Professional money moved line from +11 to +10.5. Sharps backing Wolves despite public hammering Thunder.

riskFactors: OKC is best team in the league
Wolves away from home with worse record (5-6)
SGA can take over any game

anthonyEdwards.note: Kept Wolves in game with dominant scoring performance

shaiGilgeousAlexander.note: Extended his 20+ point streak to 91 games (3rd longest ever)

quarterBreakdown.description: Thunder started strong at home. Built early lead but Wolves stayed within striking distance. Edwards aggressive from the start.
Back and forth. Minnesota's three-point shooting kept them in it (finished 46% from deep). Competitive first half.
Wolves defense tightened. Edwards continued his dominant performance. Game stayed within range for cover.
Game was within 5 with 2 minutes left. Thunder outscored Minnesota 8-1 in final 60 seconds to pad margin, but only 8-point final loss.

gameResults.whenCleared: Covered with final score 113-105 (8-point loss, needed +10.5)
gameResults.gamePace: Moderate pace. Both teams competed hard. Wolves' 46% three-point shooting was key to staying competitive.

whatWentRight.title: Anthony Edwards Delivered
whatWentRight.description: 31 points and 8 rebounds. Edwards was the engine that kept Wolves competitive against the league's best team.

whatWentRight.title: Three-Point Shooting Kept It Close
whatWentRight.description: 46% from three (despite 41% overall FG%) was the difference maker. Hit enough threes to stay within the number.

whatWentRight.title: Line Was Indeed Inflated
whatWentRight.description: Market overreacted to OKC's hot start. Final 8-point margin proved 10.5 was too many points.

whatWentRight.title: Professional Money Was Right
whatWentRight.description: Sharp movement from +11 to +10.5 indicated this was a solid play. Covered by 2.5 points.

statisticalContext.turnovers: 16 turnovers hurt but three-point shooting compensated
statisticalContext.freeThrows: 22-37 (59%) - could have covered by more with better FT shooting

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: This was edge realization, not luck. The model correctly identified that 10.5 points was too many for a playoff-caliber opponent. Edwards' 31 points was within his range and the Wolves competed as expected.

closingLineValue.verdict: Positive CLV. Got slightly better number as line moved toward Wolves. Sharp action validated.

keyTakeaways: Double-digit dogs against elite teams in NBA are often overpriced
Public loves betting favorites, creating value on quality underdogs
Anthony Edwards is a star who can keep any team competitive
Sharp money movement from +11 to +10.5 was the tell
OKC's 17-1 start created inflated public perception
Market corrections happen during the game - this was one of them
verdict: Perfect execution. Model identified inflated line, sharps confirmed the edge, and Wolves covered by 2.5 points. Edwards' 31 points kept it close. This is exactly the type of play we target.
